front.title: Safely Distributing OpenPGP Keys with Keylist Subscriptions

abstract.t: This document specifies a system by which clients may subscribe to an organization's keylist to keep its internal keystore up-to-date. Ensuring that all members of an organization have their colleagues' most recent PGP keys is critical to maintaining operational security. To enable cross-client compatibility, this document proposes a standard format for the keylist file as well as feature requirements for clients who wish to implement keylist subscription functionality.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document specifies a system by which OpenPGP clients may subscribe to a cryptographically signed keylist published by an organization. This system allows for seamless key rotation across an entire organization and enhances operational security. The user interface by which an OpenPGP client provides this functionality to the user is out of scope, as is the process by which the OpenPGP client retrieves keys. Other non-security-related implementation details are also out of scope. To enable cross-client compatibility, this document instead provides a standard format for the keylist, its cryptographic verification, and the method by which it is retreived over the Internet.

section.title: Requirements Notation
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119].

section.title: Terminology
section.t: This document uses the terms "OpenPGP", "public key", "private key", "signature", "keystore", and "fingerprint" defined by OpenPGP Message Format [RFC4880].

The term "keylist" is defined as a list of OpenPGP keys identified by their fingerprints accessible via a URI. The exact format of this data is specified in "Data Element Formats". An "authority key" is defined as the OpenPGP used to sign a particular keylist. Every keylist has a corresponding authority key, and every authority key has at least one corresponding keylist. For security purposes, a single authority key SHOULD NOT be used to sign multiple keylists.

section.title: General Functions
section.t: As new keys are created and other keys are revoked, it is critical that all members of an organization have the most recent set of keys available on their computers. Keylists enable organizations to publish a directory of OpenPGP keys that OpenPGP clients can use to keep their internal keystores up-to-date.

section.title: Subscribing to Keylists
section.t: A single OpenPGP client may subscribe to many different keylists, or none at all. When an OpenPGP client first subscribes to a keylist, it SHOULD update or import every key present in the keylist. Keylist subscriptions SHOULD be persistent--that is, they should be permanently stored by the OpenPGP client to enable future automatic updates.

To subscribe to a keylist, the OpenPGP client must be aware of the keylist URI, the keylist's signature URI, and the fingerprint of the authority key used to sign the keylist. An OpenPGP client MUST NOT employ a trust-on-first-use model for determining the fingerprint of the authority key; it must be explicitly provided by the user.

section.title: Periodic Updates
section.t: The primary purpose of keylists is to enable periodic updates of OpenPGP clients' internal keystores. We RECOMMEND that OpenPGP clients provide a default refresh interval of less than one day, however we also RECOMMEND that OpenPGP clients allow the user to select this interval.
